examItem.question: What is the supreme law of the land?
What does the Constitution do?
examItem.answer: 1. Sets up the government. 2. Defines the government. 3. Protects basic rights of Americans.

examItem.question: The idea of self-government is the first three words of the Constitution. What are these words?
What is an amendment?
examItem.answer: 1. A change (to the Constitution). 2. An Addition (to the Constitution).

examItem.question: What do we call the first ten amendments to the Constitution?
What is one right or freedom from the First Amendment?
examItem.answer: 1. Speech. 2. Religion. 3. Assembly. 4. Press. 5. Petition the government.

examItem.question: How many amendments does the Constitution have?
What did the Declaration of Independence do?
examItem.answer: 1. Announce our independence (from Great Britian). 2. Declare our independence (from Great Britian). 3. Said that the United States is free (from Great Britian).

examItem.question: What are two rights in the Declaration of Independence?
What is freedom of religion?
examItem.answer: You can practice any religion, or not practice a religion.

examItem.question: What is the economic system in the United States?
What is the "rule of law"?
examItem.answer: 1. Everyone must follow the law. 2. Leaders must obey the law. 3. Government must obey the law. 4. No one is above the law.

examItem.question: Name one branch or part of the government?
examItem.answer: 1. Congress. 2. Legislative. 3. President. 4. Executive. 5. The courts. 6. Judicial.

examItem.question: What stops one branch of government from becoming too powerful?
examItem.answer: 1. Checks and balances. 2. Separation of powers.

examItem.question: Who is in charge of the executive branch?
Who makes federal laws?
examItem.answer: 1. Congress. 2. Senate and House (of Reprentatives). 3. (U.S or national) legislature.

examItem.question: What are the two parts of the U.S Congress?
examItem.answer: The Senate and the House (of representatives).

examItem.question: How many U.S Senators are there?
We elect a U.S Senator for how many years?
Who is one of your state's U.S Senators now?
The House of Representatives has how many voting members?
We elect a U.S Representative for how many years?
Name your U.S Representative.
Who does a U.S Senator represent?
Why do some states have more representatives than other states?
We elect a U.S president for how many years?
In what month do we vote for the President?
What is the name of the President of the United States?
What is the name of the Vice President of the United States now?
If the president can no longer serve, who becomes president?
If both the president and the vice president can no longer serve, who becomes president?
Who is Commander and Chief of the military?
Who signs bills to become laws?
Who vetoes bills?
What does the President's cabinet do?
What are 2 cabinet level positions?
examItem.answer: 1. Secretary of Agriculture. 2. Secretary of Commerce. 3. Secretary of Defence. 4. Secretary of Education. 5. Secretary of Energy. 6. Secretary of Health and Human Services. 7. Secretary of Homeland Security. 8. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. 9. Secretary of the Interior. 10. Secretary of Labor. 11. Secretary of State. 12. Secretary of Transportation. 13. Secretary of Veterans Affairs. 14. Attorney General. 15. Vice President.

examItem.question: What does the judicial branch do?
examItem.answer: 1. Reviews laws. 2. Explains laws. 3. Resolves disputes. 4. Decides if a law goes against the Constitution.

examItem.question: What is the highest court in the U.S?
How many justices are on the Supreme Court?
Who is the chief justice of the United States?
Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the federal government. What is one power?
examItem.answer: 1. To print money. 2. To declare war. 3. To create an army. 4. To make treaties.

examItem.question: Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the States. What is one power?
examItem.answer: 1. To provide schooling and education. 2. Provide police protection. 3. Provide safety (fire department). 4. Give a driver's license. 5. Approve zoning and land use.

examItem.question: Who is the Governor of your state now?
What is the Capital of your state?
What are the 2 major political parties in the U.S?
What is the political party of the President now?
What is the name of the Speaker of the House of Representatives?
There are 4 amendments to the Constitution on who can vote. Describe one.
examItem.answer: 1. Citizens 18 and older. 2. You don't have to pay (a poll tax) to vote. 3. Any citizen can vote (both men and women). 4. A male citizen of any race (can vote).

examItem.question: What is 1 responsibility only for U.S citizens?
examItem.answer: 1. Serve on a jury. 2. Vote in a federal election.

examItem.question: Name 1 right only for U.S citizens.
examItem.answer: 1. Vote in a federal election. 2. Run for federal office.

examItem.question: What are 2 rights of everyone living in the U.S?
examItem.answer: 1. Freedom of expression. 2. Freedom of speech. 3. Freedom of assembly. 4. Freedom to petition the government. 5. Freedom to worship. 6. The right to bear arms.

examItem.question: What do we show loyalty to when we say the pledge of allegiance?
What is 1 promise you make when you become a U.S citizen?
examItem.answer: 1. Give up loyalty to other countries. 2. Defend the constitution and laws of the U.S 3. Obey the laws of the U.S 4. Serve in the U.S military. 5. Serve the nation. 6. Be loyal to the U.S

examItem.question: How old do citizens have to be to vote for the president?
What are 2 ways that Americans can participate in their democracy?
examItem.answer: 1. Vote. 2. Join a political party. 3. Help with a campaign. 4. Join a civic group. 5. Join a community group. 6. Give an elected official your opinion on an issue. 7. Call senators and representatives. 8. Publicaly support or oppose an issue or policy. 9. Run for office. 10. Write to a newspaper.

examItem.question: When is the last day you can send in federal income tax forms?
When must all men register for selective service?
What is 1 reason colonists came to America?
examItem.answer: 1. Freedom. 2. Political liberty. 3. Religious freedom. 4. Economic opportunity. 5. Practice their religion. 6. Escape persecution.

examItem.question: Who lived in America before the Europeans arrived?
What group of people was taken to America and sold as slaves?
Why did the colonists fight the British?
examItem.answer: 1. Because of high taxes. 2. Because the British army stayed in their houses. 3. Because they didn't have self government.

examItem.question: Who wrote the Declaration of Independence?
When was the Declaration of Independence adopted?
There were 13 original states. Name 3.
examItem.answer: 1. New Hampshire. 2. Massachusetts. 3. Rhode Island. 4. Connecticut. 5. New York. 6. New Jersey. 7. Pennsylvania. 8. Delaware. 9. Maryland. 10. Virginia. 11. North Carolina. 12. South Carolina. 13. Georgia.

examItem.question: What happened at the Constitutional Convention?
examItem.answer: The founding fathers wrote the Constitution.

examItem.question: When was the Constitution written?
The Federalist Papers supported the passage of the U.S constitution. Name one of the writers.
examItem.answer: 1. James Madison. 2. Alexander Hamilton. 3. John Jay. 4. Publius.

examItem.question: What is one thing Benjamin Franklin was famous for?
examItem.answer: 1. U.S Diplomat. 2. Oldest member in the constitutional convention. 3. First Postmaster General of the U.S. 4. Writer of 'Poor Richard's Almanac" 5. Started the first free libraries.

examItem.question: Who is the "Father of Our Country"?
Who was the first president?
What territory did the U.S buy from France in 1803?
Name one war fought by the U.S in the 1800s.
examItem.answer: 1. War of 1812. 2. Mexican-American War. 3. Civil War. 4. Spanish-American War.

examItem.question: Name the U.S war between the North and the South.
Name 1 problem that led to the Civil War.
What was one important thing Abraham Lincoln did?
examItem.answer: 1. Freed the slaves (Emancipation Proclamation). 2. Saved the Union. 3. Led the U.S during the Civil War.

examItem.question: What did the Emacipation Proclamation do?
What did Susan B. Anthony do?
examItem.answer: 1. Fought for women's rights 2. Fought for civil rights.

examItem.question: Name 1 war fought by the U.S in the 1900s.
examItem.answer: 1. World War I 2. World War II. 3. Korean War. 4. Vietnam War. 5. Gulf War.

examItem.question: Who was president during World War I?
Who was the president during the great depression and World War II?
Who did the U.S fight in WWII?
Before he was president, Eisenhower was a general. What war was he in?
During the Cold War, what was the main concern of the U.S?
What movement tried to end racial discrimination?
What did Martin Luther King Jr do?
examItem.answer: 1. Fought for civil rights. 2. Worked for equality for all Americans.

examItem.question: What major event happened on Sept 11, 2011 in the U.S?
Name 1 American Indian tribe in the U.S?
Name 1 of the two longest rivers in the U.S
What ocean is on the West Coast of the U.S?
What ocean is on the East Coast of the U.S
Name 1 U.S territory.
examItem.answer: 1. Puerto Rico. 2. U.S Virgin Islands. 3. American Samoa. 4. Northern Mariana Islands. 5. Guam.

examItem.question: Name 1 state that borders Canada.
examItem.answer: 1. Maine 2. New Hampshire. 3. Vermont. 4. New York. 5. Pennsylvania 6. Ohio. 7. Michigan. 8. Minnesota. 9. North Dakota. 10. Montana. 11. Idaho. 12. Washington. 13. Alaska.

examItem.question: Name 1 state that borders Mexico.
What is the capital of the U.S?
Where is the Statue of Liberty?
Why does the flag have 13 stripes?
Why does the flag have 50 stars?
What is the name of the national anthem?
When do we celebrate Independence Day?
Name 2 national U.S. holidays.
examItem.answer: 1. Independence Day. 2. Christmas. 3. New Year's Day.
